awd_titl_txt: Assessing Complex Collaborative STEM Learning at Scale with Epistemic Network Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
This project was submitted in response to EHR Core Research (ECR) program announcement NSF 15-509. The ECR program of fundamental research in STEM education provides funding in critical research areas that are essential, broad and enduring. EHR seeks proposals that will help synthesize, build and/or expand research foundations in the following focal areas: STEM learning, STEM learning environments, STEM workforce development, and broadening participation in STEM. The ECR program is distinguished by its emphasis on the accumulation of robust evidence to inform efforts to (a) understand, (b) build theory to explain, and (c) suggest interventions (and innovations) to address persistent challenges in STEM interest, education, learning, and participation.

In this project, researchers will develop a statistical analysis technique for measuring how people learn. With prior NSF funding, members of the team created epistemic network analysis (ENA), a technique for creating network models of complex and collaborative thinking in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. ENA is being used by more than 40 researchers at 19 universities to answer a wide range of research questions in learning sciences, cognitive neuroscience, engineering education, environmental science education, medical and surgical education, and history of science. The proposed research and development will create an online toolkit that lets researchers upload audio, video, text, or log-file data, automatically transcribe the audio data, develop and validate automated codes using supervised natural language processing tools, and produce ENA models. This will make it possible for researchers analyze data on how people learn without requiring simultaneous expertise in automated transcription, data segmentation, coding, and network modeling. It will also make it possible to conduct analyses of learning using the large volumes of data that are currently generated by online learning tools, significantly expanding capacity for research on learning.

In this project, the research team will conduct fundamental research on learning in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) by developing and extending a theory-based statistical analysis technique for using network analysis to model complex and collaborative STEM thinking (CCST). With prior NSF funding, members of the team created epistemic network analysis (ENA), a technique for creating dynamic models of CCST. Data on CCST typically come in one of two forms: Video and audio recordings of interactions from classrooms and workplaces, or log files from online interactions. Data in audio or video form must be transcribed. Text data from recordings or log files have to be coded, or annotated to indicate what elements of CCST are present in the data, and where those elements are located. With existing tools, researchers must complete these steps by hand, or use their own techniques for automated transcription and coding. However, many skilled CCST researchers are not simultaneously experts in the sciences of automated transcription, automated identification, validation, and application of codes, and network analysis. The proposed research and development will create ENAlysis, an online toolkit that provides a seamless, automated analysis pipeline from raw data to final results. The project will thus develop innovative methods for measuring STEM learning and expand access to a proven, theory-based technique for analyzing CCST. The result will be expanded use of powerful learning analytic techniques to model CCST, which will significantly improve assessment of STEM thinking and learning and inform policy and practice.

por.por_cntn:
Analyzing Complex, Collaborative Thinking and Learning with Quantitative Ethnography

We live in an age of big data, but the capacity this brings to measure and analyze learning is tempered by the danger of reinforcing bias and injustice. In this project, the Epistemic Analytics lab at the University of Wisconsin?Madison developed methods and tools that address the challenges associated with analyzing massive amounts of data in order to understand complex phenomena such as learning and collaboration. This project focused on the development of methods, statistical techniques, and user-friendly systems for implementing them because researchers need not only new ways to analyze big data but also entirely new approaches to thinking about big data. Thus, this project significantly expanded a novel method for modeling learning and other complex phenomena: quantitative ethnography.

Quantitative ethnography addresses one of the most significant challenges in the analysis of learning. It provides the theoretical and technical capacities to combine statistical inference with the interpretive power of grounded, qualitative data analysis in contexts where large amounts of rich data are available. Classical statistical techniques were not designed to handle massive quantities of data, and no human could read, let alone analyze qualitatively, even a fraction of most educational datasets. Quantitative ethnography makes it possible to construct deep qualitative assessments of learning at scale. Importantly, the method addresses the short-comings of traditional qualitative and quantitative approaches: the former risks finding phenomena that are not representative of broader patterns, while the latter risks finding arbitrary patterns that are bound to exist in any large collection of data or perpetuating subgroup biases, which may be masked by patterns in majority groups. By unifying qualitative and quantitative methods, QE enables researchers to conduct analyses that are fair, grounded, and scalable.

In addition to QE methods, this project has significantly extended QE tools, such as epistemic network analysis (ENA; app.epistemicnetwork.org), and developed new statistical techniques, including tools for automated text classification and tools that enable researchers to construct interactive, web-based versions of QE models that teachers, policy-makers, or other stakeholders can use to explore research findings. A key challenge for QE scholars, however, is linking different analytic processes together, so this project produced the QE Studio, which provides researchers with a single workspace that makes management, replication, and reporting of analytic work easier and more transparent.

Collectively, this work has led to the establishment of the International Society for Quantitative Ethnography (ISQE; qesoc.org/), a professional association for researchers engaged in QE scholarship. ISQE hosts an annual international conference, a regular webinar series, workshops, and other events for more than 500 QE scholars in more than 30 countries. In the past five years, more than 1,600 publications have used or referenced QE methods or techniques to address critical questions in a wide range of fields, including education, computer science, medicine, engineering, and more.

To learn more about quantitative ethnography, ENA, and other QE tools developed by the Epistemic Analytics lab, visit http://epistemicanalytics.org/.
